text: Smoothing, Fudging, and Ordering Yi Sun MOP 2010 1 Warmup Problem 1 (China 2004). Find the largest positive real k, such that for any positive reals a, b, c, d, we have (a + b + c) [ 81(a + b + c + d) 5 + 16(a + b + c + 2d) 5] ≥ kabcd3. Problem 2 (MOP 2002). For a, b, c positive reals, prove that ( 2a b + c ) 2 3 + ( 2b c + a ) 2 3 + ( 2c a + b ) 2 3 ≥ 3. 2 Useful Techniques In this lecture we discuss several more ad-hoc methods of attacking inequalities: • Smoothing: Suppose you wish to prove an inequality of the form f (x1, x2, . . . , xn) ≥ C with the constraint x1+· · ·+xn = k. If equality holds when all xi are equal, then, heuristically, you can try to make f (x1, x2, . . . , xn) smaller by “moving the xi together.” Rigorously, this means showing inequalities of the form f (x1, x2, . . . , xn) ≥ f (k/n, x1 + x2 − k/n, . . . , xn). • Isolated Fudging: Given an inequality of the form f (a, b, c) + f (b, c, a) + f (c, a, b) ≥ k, we can try to bound each term individually by f (a, b, c) ≥ k ar ar + br + cr for some r. More generally, it is useful to attempt to modify each portion of an inequality separately. • Ordering: It can be useful to assume an order on the variables in an inequality. Suppose it is possible to write an inequality in the form Sa(b − c) 2 + Sb(c − a)2 + Sc(a − b)2 ≥ 0 for some Sa, Sb, Sc. In this case, if the ordering a ≥ b ≥ c induces an appropriate ordering on some linear functions of Sa, Sb, Sc, we may imitate the proof of Schur to obtain the result. 1 3 Useful Facts Throughout this section, we refer to convex functions. We say that f is convex if f ′′(x) ≥ 0 for all x or if λf (x) + (1 − λ)f (y) ≥ f (λx + (1 − λ)y) for all 0 ≤ λ ≤ 1 and x < y. We will also refer to the concept of majorization; we say that the sequence a1, . . . , an majorizes the sequence b1, . . . , bn if a1 + · · · + ai ≥ b1 + · · · + bi for i < n and a1 + · · · + an = b1 + · · · + bn. Theorem 1 (Weighted Jensen). Let f be a convex function, x1, . . . , xn real numbers, and a1, . . . , an non-negative reals with a1 + · · · + an = 1. Then, we have a1f (x1) + · · · + anf (xn) ≥ f (a1x1 + · · · + anxn) . Theorem 2 (Karamata). Let f be convex. Then, for x1, . . . , xn and y1, . . . , yn such that the {xi} majorize the {yi}, we have f (x1) + · · · + f (xn) ≥ f (y1) + · · · + f (yn). Theorem 3 (Schur). For non-negative reals x, y, z and r > 0, we have xr(x − y)(x − z) + yr(y − x)(y − z) + zr(z − x)(z − y) ≥ 0 where equality holds if x = y = z or {x, y, z} = {0, a, a} for some a. 4 Problems 4.1 Smoothing Problem 3 (USAMO 1980). Show that for all non-negative reals a, b, c ≤ 1, a b + c + 1 + b c + a + 1 + c a + b + 1 + (1 − a)(1 − b)(1 − c) ≤ 1. Problem 4 (USAMO 1999). Let a1, a2, . . . , an (n > 3) be real numbers such that a1 + a2 + · · · + an ≥ n and a 2 1 + a 2 2 + · · · + a2 n ≥ n2. Prove that max(a1, a2, . . . , an) ≥ 2. Problem 5 (USAMO 1998). Let a1, . . . , an be real numbers in the interval (0, π 2 ) such that tan (a0 − π 4 ) + tan (a1 − π 4 ) + · · · + tan (an − π 4 ) ≥ n − 1. Prove that tan(a0) · tan(a1) · · · · · tan(an) ≥ nn+1. Problem 6 (IMO 1974). Determine all possible values of S = a a + b + d + b a + b + c + c b + c + d + d a + c + d where a, b, c, d are arbitrary positive numbers. 2 Problem 7 (Vietnam 1998). Let x1, . . . , xn be positive numbers satisfying 1 x1 + 1998 + 1 x2 + 1998 + · · · + 1 xn + 1998 = 1 1998 . Prove that n√x1x2 · · · xn n − 1 ≥ 1998. 4.2 Fudging Problem 8 (IMO 2001). Prove that for all positive real numbers a, b, c, a √a2 + 8bc + b √b2 + 8ca + c √c2 + 8ab ≥ 1. Problem 9 (USAMO 2004). Let a, b, c > 0. Prove that (a 5 − a 2 + 3)(b 5 − b 2 + 3)(c 5 − c 2 + 3) ≥ (a + b + c)3. Problem 10 (USAMO 2003). Let a, b, c be positive real numbers. Prove that (2a + b + c)2 2a2 + (b + c)2 + (2b + c + a)2 2b2 + (c + a)2 + (2c + a + b)2 2c2 + (a + b)2 ≤ 8. Problem 11 (IMO 2005). Let x, y, z be three positive reals such that xyz ≥ 1. Prove that x5 − x2 x5 + y2 + z2 + y5 − y2 x2 + y5 + z2 + z5 − z2 x2 + y2 + z5 ≥ 0. Problem 12 (Japan 1997). Show that for all positive reals a, b, c, (a + b − c)2 (a + b)2 + c2 + (b + c − a)2 (b + c)2 + a2 + (c + a − b)2 (c + a)2 + b2 ≥ 3 5 . 4.3 Ordering Problem 13. Prove Schur’s Inequality. Problem 14 (USAMO 2001). Let a, b, c be non-negative reals such that a2 + b 2 + c 2 + abc = 4. Prove that 0 ≤ ab + bc + ca − abc ≤ 2. Problem 15. Prove that for any positive reals a, b, c, (a 2 + b 2 + c 2) 2 ≥ 3(a 3b + b 3c + c 3a). Problem 16 (TST 2009). Prove that for positive real numbers x, y, z, we have x3(y2 + z2) 2 + y3(z2 + x2)2 + z3(x2 + y2) 2 ≥ xyz[xy(x + y) 2 + yz(y + z) 2 + zx(z + x)2]. 3 4.4 Bonus Weird Inequalities Problem 17 (ISL 2001). Let x1, x2, . . . , xn be real numbers. Prove that x1 1 + x2 1 + x2 1 + x2 1 + x2 2 + · · · + xn 1 + x2 1 + · · · + x2 n < √n. Problem 18 (IMO 2004). Let n ≥ 3 be an integer. Let t1, t2, . . . , tn be positive real numbers such that n2 + 1 > (t1 + t2 + · · · + tn) ( 1 t1 + 1 t2 + · · · + 1 tn ) . Show that ti, tj, tk are side lengths of a triangle for all i, j, k with 1 ≤ i < j < k ≤ n. Problem 19 (Russia 2004). Let n > 3 be an integer and let x1, x2, . . . , xn be positive reals with product 1. Prove that 1 1 + x1 + x1x2 + 1 1 + x2 + x2x3 + · · · + 1 1 + xn + xnx1 > 1. Problem 20 (Romania 2004). Let n ≥ 2 be an integer and let a1, a2, . . . , an be real numbers. Prove that for any non-empty subset S ⊂ {1, 2, . . . , n}, we have ( ∑ i∈S ai )2 ≤ ∑ 1≤i≤j≤n (ai + · · · + aj)2. 4
